text: Anti-immunoglobulin M activates nuclear <extra_id_0> calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human B lymphocytes .

We and others have previously shown that the nuclear protein , <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is phosphorylated in a calcium - dependent manner after ligation of immunoglobulin ( Ig ) M on B lymphocytes .

As this phosphorylation was independent of protein kinase C activity , we tested whether a calcium / calmodulin - dependent protein kinase ( CaM kinase ) might phosphorylate the <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein after elevation of intracellular free calcium concentrations .
The dephosphorylated form of <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been shown to bind to chromatin , suggesting that the operative kinase should be detectable in the nucleus .

We prepared nuclear extracts from two human B cell lines in which increased intracellular free calcium levels correlated with increased phosphorylation of the <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .
Activity of the CaM kinases was determined using a synthetic peptide substrate both in the absence and presence of an inhibitor specific for the CaM kinase family , KN-62 .
Stimulation of cells with anti-IgM led to increased activity of a nuclear kinase that could phosphorylate the peptide , and this activity was reduced by 10 microM KN-62 .
Kinase activity was reduced in lysates preadsorbed using an antibody specific for <extra_id_0> CaM kinase II <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Two-dimensional phosphopeptide maps of the <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein from cells incubated with ionomycin or anti-IgM contained two unique phosphopeptides that were absent in untreated cells .

Incubation of isolated <extra_id_0> Ets-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein with purified <extra_id_0> CaM kinase II <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> produced phosphorylation of peptides that migrated identically to those found in cells incubated with either anti-IgM or ionomycin .

These data suggest a model of signal transduction by the antigen receptor on B lymphocytes in which increased intracellular free calcium can rapidly activate nuclear <extra_id_0> CaM kinase II <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , potentially resulting in phosphorylation and regulation of DNA - binding proteins .
